appointments.chief_complaint: Progressive lower back pain with leg weakness and walking difficulty for 6 months

clinical_notes.subjective: 68-year-old patient reports gradual onset of lower back pain over 6 months. Pain 7/10, constant, worse with walking. Can only walk 100 meters before leg weakness and numbness force her to stop. Legs feel heavy and weak. Pain improves with sitting and bending forward. No trauma.
clinical_notes.objective: Antalgic gait. Positive Romberg test. Reduced sensation in both feet. Weakness in ankle dorsiflexion bilaterally 4/5. Hyperreflexia in both legs. Positive Babinski sign bilaterally. No saddle anesthesia.
clinical_notes.assessment: Lumbar spinal stenosis with neurogenic claudication
clinical_notes.plan: Urgent referral to neurosurgeon. Order lumbar MRI. Consider surgical intervention given severity of symptoms.

appointments.chief_complaint: Urgent referral for lumbar spinal stenosis with neurogenic claudication

clinical_notes.subjective: 6-month history of progressive lower back pain with severe walking limitation. Patient can only walk 100 meters before leg weakness forces her to stop. Legs feel heavy and weak. Pain improves with sitting and forward bending. Significantly impacts daily activities.
clinical_notes.objective: Severe antalgic gait. Positive Romberg test. Reduced sensation in both feet. Weakness in ankle dorsiflexion bilaterally 4/5. Hyperreflexia in both legs. Positive Babinski sign bilaterally. No saddle anesthesia or bowel/bladder dysfunction.
clinical_notes.assessment: Severe lumbar spinal stenosis with neurogenic claudication and myelopathic signs
clinical_notes.plan: Urgent lumbar MRI to confirm diagnosis and assess severity. Consider surgical decompression if significant stenosis confirmed. This is a surgical emergency given myelopathic signs.

appointments.referral_to: Radiologie am Sendlinger Tor - urgent lumbar MRI

appointments.chief_complaint: Urgent MRI for lumbar spinal stenosis

clinical_notes.subjective: MRI performed urgently for suspected lumbar spinal stenosis with myelopathic signs.
clinical_notes.objective: MRI shows severe central canal stenosis at L3-L4 and L4-L5 with significant spinal cord compression. Facet joint hypertrophy and ligamentum flavum hypertrophy contributing to stenosis.
clinical_notes.assessment: Severe lumbar spinal stenosis with spinal cord compression
clinical_notes.plan: Urgent surgical decompression required. Conservative treatment not appropriate given severity of stenosis and myelopathic signs.

appointments.referral_to: Prof. Dr. Wagner - urgent surgical consultation

appointments.chief_complaint: MRI results review and surgical planning

clinical_notes.subjective: Patient reports continued severe walking limitation. Can only walk 50 meters now. Leg weakness worsening. Pain constant 8/10.
clinical_notes.objective: MRI confirms severe central canal stenosis at L3-L4 and L4-L5 with spinal cord compression. Myelopathic signs present. No improvement with conservative treatment.
clinical_notes.assessment: Severe lumbar spinal stenosis requiring urgent surgical decompression
clinical_notes.plan: Recommend L3-L5 laminectomy with decompression. Surgery scheduled for next week. Pre-operative evaluation completed. Patient understands risks and benefits.

clinical_notes.subjective: Pre-operative assessment for planned laminectomy. Patient understands procedure and risks.
clinical_notes.objective: L3-L5 laminectomy with decompression performed successfully. Spinal cord decompressed. No complications during surgery.
clinical_notes.plan: Post-operative care. Gradual mobilization. Physical therapy to begin in 2 weeks. Follow-up in 2 weeks.

clinical_notes.subjective: Patient reports dramatic improvement. Can now walk 500 meters without stopping. Leg weakness much improved. Back pain reduced to 3/10. Very satisfied with surgery.
clinical_notes.objective: Surgical wound healing well. Neurological examination shows significant improvement. Walking distance increased. No myelopathic signs. Reflexes normalizing.
clinical_notes.plan: Continue gradual mobilization. Start physical therapy next week. Return to normal activities in 6 weeks. Follow-up in 6 weeks.

scans.indication: Severe lumbar spinal stenosis with neurogenic claudication and myelopathic signs. Rule out spinal cord compression.
scans.technique: Multi-sequence MRI of lumbar spine performed without intravenous contrast.
findings: Severe central canal stenosis at L3-L4 and L4-L5
Significant spinal cord compression at both levels
Facet joint hypertrophy contributing to stenosis
Mild degenerative changes throughout lumbar spine
scans.impression: Severe lumbar spinal stenosis with spinal cord compression at L3-L4 and L4-L5. Surgical decompression required.
scans.recommendation: Urgent surgical consultation for laminectomy and decompression. Conservative treatment not appropriate given severity of stenosis.

doctor_comments.content: Urgent MRI findings discussed with Prof. Wagner immediately. Severe lumbar spinal stenosis with spinal cord compression at L3-L4 and L4-L5. This is a surgical emergency given the myelopathic signs and severe stenosis. Conservative treatment is not appropriate. Patient requires urgent surgical decompression to prevent permanent neurological damage. Risk of paralysis if surgery delayed.

Patient presents with severe lumbar spinal stenosis and myelopathic signs. MRI shows significant spinal cord compression at L3-L4 and L4-L5. Given the severity of symptoms and myelopathic signs, surgical decompression is the only appropriate treatment. Patient is elderly (68) but otherwise healthy. L3-L5 laminectomy planned. This case demonstrates the importance of timely surgical intervention for severe spinal stenosis with myelopathy.

Excellent post-operative recovery after L3-L5 laminectomy. Patient's walking distance increased from 100 meters to 500 meters. Leg weakness significantly improved. This case demonstrates the dramatic improvement possible with surgical decompression for severe spinal stenosis. Patient is very satisfied with outcome. Physical therapy will help with further recovery and strengthening.
